item.title: Vince add a quote by Steven Owen Godersky
item.description: "The best is a tale that has yet to be written." -- Steven Owen Godersky

item.title: Vince add a quote by Voltaire
item.description: "Despite the enormous quantity of books, how few people read! And if one reads profitably, one would realize how much stupid stuff the vulgar herd is content to swallow every day." -- Voltaire

item.title: Vince add a quote by Henrik Ibsen
item.description: "To live is to war with trolls." -- Henrik Ibsen

item.title: Vince add a quote by William Shakespeare
item.description: "I despised my arrival on this earth and I despise my departure; it is a tragedy." -- William Shakespeare

item.title: Vince add a quote by Pauline Ashwell
item.description: "We cannot resist everything; we can only choose the forces to which we will submit." -- Pauline Ashwell

item.title: Vince add a quote by Meister Eckhart
item.description: "God is not good, or else he could do better." -- Meister Eckhart

item.title: Vince add a quote by Fyodor Dostoyevsky
item.description: "Drowning men, it is said, cling to wisps of straw." -- Fyodor Dostoyevsky

item.title: Vince add a quote by John Milton
item.description: "Better to reign in Hell, than to serve in Heaven." -- John Milton

item.title: Vince add a quote by Franz Kafka
item.description: "It receives you when you come and dismisses you when you go." -- Franz Kafka

item.title: Vince add a quote by Thomas Wolfe
item.description: "The whole conviction of my life now rests upon the belief that loneliness, far from being a rare and curious phenomenon, is the central and inevitable fact of human existence." -- Thomas Wolfe

item.title: Vince add a quote by Fyodor Dostoyevsky
item.description: "In a morbid condition, dreams are often distinguished by their remarkably graphic, vivid, and extremely lifelike quality. The resulting picture is sometimes monstrous, but the setting and the whole process of the presentation sometimes happen to be so probable, and with details so subtle, unexpected, yet artistically consistent with the whole fullness of the picture, that even the dreamer himself would be unable to invent them in reality, though he were as much an artist as Pushkin or Turgenev. Such dreams, morbid dreams, are always long remembered and produce a strong impression on the disturbed and already excited organism of the person.Raskolnikov had a terrible dream." -- Fyodor Dostoyevsky

item.title: Vince add a quote by Harlan Ellison
item.description: "The only thing worth writing about is people. People. Human beings. Men and women whose individuality must be created, line by line, insight by insight. If you do not do it, the story is a failure. [...] There is no nobler chore in the universe than holding up the mirror of reality and turning it slightly, so we have a new and different perception of the commonplace, the everyday, the 'normal', the obvious. People are reflected in the glass. The fantasy situation into which you thrust them is the mirror itself. And what we are shown should illuminate and alter our perception of the world around us. Failing that, you have failed totally." -- Harlan Ellison

item.title: Vince add a quote by Philip K. Dick
item.description: "The basic tool for the manipulation of reality is the manipulation of words. If you can control the meaning of words, you can control the people who must use them." -- Philip K. Dick

item.title: Vince add a quote by Arthur C. Clarke
item.description: "Science is the only religion of mankind." -- Arthur C. Clarke

item.title: Vince add a quote by Rumi
item.description: "Pain is a treasure, for it contains mercies." -- Rumi

item.title: Vince add a quote by Rumi Jalalud-Din
item.description: "Although you see the pit, you cannot avoid it." -- Rumi Jalalud-Din

item.title: Vince add a quote by Rumi Jalalud-Din
item.description: "Two there are who are never satisfied -- the lover of the world and the lover of knowledge." -- Rumi Jalalud-Din

item.title: Vince add a quote by Fyodor Dostoyevsky
item.description: "Filled with rapture, his soul yearned for freedom, space, vastness. Over him the heavenly dome, full of quiet, shining stars, hung boundlessly. From the zenith to the horizon the still-dim Milky Way stretched its double strand. Night, fresh and quiet, almost unstirring, enveloped the earth. The white towers and golden domes of the church gleamed in the sapphire sky. The luxuriant autumn asleep till morning. The silence of the earth seemed to merge with the silence of the heavens and the mystery of the earth touched the mystery of the stars." -- Fyodor Dostoyevsky

item.title: Vince add a quote by Arthur C. Clarke
item.description: "For if not true, they are well imagined..." -- Arthur C. Clarke

item.title: Vince add a quote by Robert Bloch
item.description: "So I had this problem -- work or starve. So I thought I'd combine the two and decided to become a writer." -- Robert Bloch

item.title: Vince add a quote by Vladimir Nabokov
item.description: "Theoretically there is no absolute proof that one's awakening in the morning (the finding oneself again in the saddle of one's personality) is not really a quite unprecedented event, a perfectly original birth." -- Vladimir Nabokov

item.title: Vince add a quote by Francis Bacon
item.description: "For no man can forbid the spark nor tell whence it may come." -- Francis Bacon

item.title: Vince add a quote by Aristotle
item.description: "Whosoever is delighted in solitude, is either a wild beast or a god." -- Aristotle

item.title: Vince add a quote by Jack Kirby
item.description: "All life on Earth is subject to the rumbles and rockings of the parent stucture which has no control over the disastrous effects of its stresses and strains on whatever thrives on its surface. The ambitions and dreams of men are irrelevant to this planetary giant which pursues its own way in its own manner. Man is its child, tenant and still, to this date, its captive." -- Jack Kirby

item.title: Vince add a quote by Isaac Asimov
item.description:
"A number of years ago, when I was a freshly-appointed instructor, I met, for the first time, a certain eminent historian of science. At the time I could only regard him with tolerant condescension.
I was sorry of the man who, it seemed to me, was forced to hover about the edges of science. He was compelled to shiver endlessly in the outskirts, getting only feeble warmth from the distant sun of science- in-progress; while I, just beginning my research, was bathed in the heady liquid heat up at the very center of the glow.
In a lifetime of being wrong at many a point, I was never more wrong. It was I, not he, who was wandering in the periphery. It was he, not I, who lived in the blaze.
I had fallen victim to the fallacy of the 'growing edge;' the belief that only the very frontier of scientific advance counted; that everything that had been left behind by that advance was faded and dead.
But is that true? Because a tree in spring buds and comes greenly into leaf, are those leaves therefore the tree? If the newborn twigs and their leaves were all that existed, they would form a vague halo of green suspended in mid-air, but surely that is not the tree. The leaves, by themselves, are no more than trivial fluttering decoration. It is the trunk and limbs that give the tree its grandeur and the leaves themselves their meaning.
There is not a discovery in science, however revolutionary, however sparkling with insight, that does not arise out of what went before. 'If I have seen further than other men,' said [author:Isaac Newton|135106], 'it is because I have stood on the shoulders of giants." -- Isaac Asimov

item.title: Vince add a quote by Douglas Adams
item.description: "Let the past hold on to itself and let the present move forward into the future." -- Douglas Adams

item.title: Vince add a quote by Stéphane Mallarme
item.description: "The world exists to end up in a book." -- Stéphane Mallarme

item.title: Vince add a quote by James Patrick Kelly
item.description: "The walls are everywhere. Limits. You're not smart enough, not rich enough. You get tired. You die. Some people like to pretend they've broken out. That they're running free. But there's no escape. You have to find a way to live within the walls. And then, they don't matter." -- James Patrick Kelly

item.title: Vince add a quote by Guy de Maupassant
item.description: "Certainly solitude is dangerous for active minds. We require around us men who can think and talk. When we are alone for a long time, we people space with phantoms." -- Guy de Maupassant

item.title: Vince add a quote by Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
item.description: "One must wait till it comes." -- Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
